6.29.text:
(Music and singing.)
TROY KENNEDY: We want to invite you wherever

9.99.text:
you are, whenever you're watching this, to
join us in the living room here. We gather

18.00.text:
here together in the great name of Jesus to
bring him a sacrifice praise for no other

24.00.text:
reason than he is worthy.
(Music and singing.)

782.50.text:
TROY KENNEDY: Jesus, we offer all this from
hearts who stand humbled and in awe before

793.49.text:
you. Amen.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Beginning eight years ago,

803.31.text:
we made a shift in something we do at the
end of each year. We took the lowest attended

809.41.text:
Sunday of the year, which is always the one
between Christmas and New Year's -- and that

815.07.text:
makes sense that it's low attendance. People
are traveling. Almost everybody's come to

819.99.text:
a Christmas service. There's lots going on.
But for years, it was our lowest Sunday. And

826.05.text:
we decided let's do something that makes a
theological statement and that also fixes

831.85.text:
this low attended weekend. So we designed
"The Church Has Left the Building." And I

838.39.text:
love that phrase, guys.
ROB WEGNER: Uh-huh.

839.66.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And I know you-all --
ROB WEGNER: Me too.

840.57.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: -- are big on it too. Because
the church is not the buildings. It's not

843.83.text:
the campus. It's not the facility. The church
is the people.

847.25.text:
ROB WEGNER: Uh-huh.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And we said, "Let's get out

849.19.text:
and get as many folks as we can to join us
on that Sunday between Christmas and New Year's

856.00.text:
to watch Westside online, to introduce them
to Westside in an easier setting." So literally

864.22.text:
the lowest attended physically-present weekend
of the year has become the highest attended

875.09.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And Jason Morris, our Internet
pastor, is having an aneurysm over here.

880.72.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: It's pretty cool stuff. So
wherever you're joining us today, we are thrilled

885.74.text:
that you are here. You may be in a living
room with family or friends, in-laws, out-laws,

891.78.text:
ex-laws. There's no telling. You may be driving
down the road. If you are, please listen;

896.37.text:
don't watch. But wherever you're joining us
today, it's our honor to talk to you for a

902.02.text:
few minutes about two things really: The great
story God has written this year at Westside

907.58.text:
and the continuing story that we're excited
about him writing in the year ahead. So I

913.19.text:
have my partners in crime: Brian -- the crazy
one -- Phipps, on this side, and Rob -- the

920.37.text:
missional man -- Wegner, on this side. And
we're just going to talk for a few minutes

924.98.text:
about the God thing that's going on.
Guys, it really has been an amazing year at

929.80.text:
Westside.
ROB WEGNER: Yeah, without a doubt. And, you

931.82.text:
know, this service in particular is symbolic,
because the most primal expression of the

938.77.text:
church in the book of Acts was the church
that met in the homes.

942.38.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Yeah.
ROB WEGNER: You know, there were the public

943.93.text:
gatherings, but when the persecution hit in
Jerusalem, the public gatherings shut down.

949.11.text:
But the Church didn't stop. It spread from
household to household to household. And that's

954.22.text:
the vibe of this gathering today.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And that's what happened

956.35.text:
for 300 years --
ROB WEGNER: That's right.

957.97.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: -- Rob, met in homes. And
we meet in homes and in big gatherings even

962.68.text:
to this day.
Brian, talk about the great year we've had.

965.44.text:
Go with it, man.
BRIAN PHIPPS: Well, I just wanted to add to

966.86.text:
what Rob said. I think it's also symbolic
that the one year where Westside actually

971.51.text:
adds on to its current building is the year
that the body is realizing more and more it's

976.67.text:
not about the building.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.

978.00.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: That's pretty crazy for a church
to both --

979.83.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.
BRIAN PHIPPS: -- increase the building and

981.72.text:
realize that this is a tool, but it's not
the answer.

984.62.text:
ROB WEGNER: Right on.
BRIAN PHIPPS: So I really love that parallel

987.70.text:
as well. So what did you ask me to talk about?
(Laughter.)

989.48.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: How good a year it's been.
BRIAN PHIPPS: It's been a great year at Westside.

992.93.text:
Actually, there are several things to talk
about. One of my favorite here is 661 baptisms

998.90.text:
just this year.
JASON MORRIS: Wow.

999.72.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Is that cool?
ROB WEGNER: Go, God.

1001.21.text:
(Applause.)
BRIAN PHIPPS: I mean, you've got friends,

1002.75.text:
you've got family who have been a part of
this. And there's been guys that I've been

1007.10.text:
serving who have been a part of that too,
and there's --

1008.58.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Oh, yeah.
BRIAN PHIPPS: -- nothing like it.

1009.45.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: The fun part for me is a
guy I led to Christ five years ago and got

1014.41.text:
baptized then actually helped baptize somebody
he led to Christ --

1018.01.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: That's the deal.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: -- this year. And I'm going

1019.66.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I mean, that -- that's just
a cool moment, because it says clearly they've

1024.30.text:
surrendered their lives to Christ.
BRIAN PHIPPS: Yeah. It's a celebration.

1026.07.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And that's what we like about
that.

1027.59.text:
What else this year, dude?
ROB WEGNER: Secondly, we have a story of new

1031.09.text:
churches that is emerging, especially internationally.
We're to a place now where in Thailand in

1036.70.text:
Laos, there's 130 churches, most of which
are actually house churches, because they're

1041.23.text:
in Laos which is a communist country. And
there they are oppressed. There is a decree.

1046.34.text:
It's called Decree 92. They cannot have permission
to gather without getting permission from

1052.92.text:
a communist government which isn't going to
happen.

1055.41.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: No.
ROB WEGNER: But one of the guys that actually

1057.71.text:
Jamo and I met recently on our last trip there
where we were training, this guy's been to

1063.04.text:
jail -- get this -- four different times.
And the last time --

1067.05.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: For being a pastor.
ROB WEGNER: For being a pastor.

1068.78.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Not for doing drugs.
ROB WEGNER: That's right.

1070.37.text:
ROB WEGNER: That's right.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Okay.

1071.30.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Thanks for --
ROB WEGNER: That makes a big difference.

1072.65.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: -- the clarification.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah, it does. Yeah.

1074.49.text:
ROB WEGNER: And the last time, they actually
tortured him. And if you look at that movement

1079.79.text:
of 130 house churches, 60 of them trace their
origin back to this one man. And one of those

1086.74.text:
ROB WEGNER: -- they've swept up all the street
orphans, and they care for all those kids

1090.74.text:
now in their homes. And because of that, the
local magistrate has given them permission

1096.06.text:
to meet publically in a communist country.
That's a God thing. That's just --

1100.19.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: It's huge.
ROB WEGNER: -- one story behind 130 of these

1102.16.text:
churches.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And that's just like God

1103.85.text:
to give favor, because they're caring for
orphans, to allow them to meet. And the cool

1109.56.text:
thing is we care for a thousand orphans around
the world now that are in facilities that

1115.32.text:
Westside supports. But that movement is caring
for probably another thousand that's literally

1121.23.text:
kids they've taken off the streets into their
own homes.

1125.01.text:
So it's been about baptisms, it's been about
church expansion, and really it's just been

1129.98.text:
about changed lives altogether.
ROB WEGNER: Uh-huh.

1132.14.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Thousands of changed lives.
That's a cool thing. Our 11 locations and

1137.19.text:
church plants in Kansas City are about 6,000
strong now. Our international presence is

1143.21.text:
even bigger than that. I think it's really
cool that more Westsiders speak Southeast

1148.25.text:
Asia languages than speak English. So it's
been a year of God's favor. And I think it's

1154.26.text:
totally appropriate just to give him a hand.
So join us even in your home.

1158.37.text:
(Applause and cheers.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: It's been cool.

1161.63.text:
Well, Brian, I think one of the best parts
is that the story is not done. God is still

1167.55.text:
writing his story, and he's still allowing
us to be part of that. We're characters in

1172.38.text:
the story.
BRIAN PHIPPS: Yeah. And it's a long, long

1174.57.text:
story. It didn't start just about 10 years
ago.

1176.81.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: No.
BRIAN PHIPPS: You know, it started a long,

1179.26.text:
long time ago. Way back in the beginning of
the book, God started to have a relationship

1183.62.text:
with his people, you know, and things have
gone well in those relationships. Things have

1188.54.text:
gone bad in those relationships. But he, from
the beginning of the book, all the way till

1192.56.text:
the end of the book that we know as the Bible,
has been chasing his people. And it says right

1198.51.text:
there when Jesus came after his death and
resurrection, he sent us his spirit so that

1203.50.text:
he could continue to live in, through, and
beyond us to keep the story of redemption

1209.87.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Basically, you could take the
whole Bible and break it down into two major

1216.18.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Act 2: He came to fix it. And
the cool part about it is he's engaged us

1221.56.text:
into that process. He hasn't said, "Sit and
watch this." He said, "Get in the game and

1226.63.text:
make it happen." And I love that part of the
story.

1229.41.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: So to capitalize on this
story that God's been writing for thousands

1234.02.text:
of years, since the beginning of man, we decided
to do something fun this year that thousands

1240.17.text:
of churches nationwide are doing or have done.
It's a movement around this idea of the story.

1247.48.text:
And, Rob, I think you've been more fired up
than any of us, but you're always more fired

1252.57.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Talk about that a little
bit. What are we going to do in 2016?

1255.19.text:
ROB WEGNER: Well, we're going to go on a journey.
And we're going to start at the very beginning

1259.50.text:
of the story, go back through the primordial
mist to the origin of time.

1265.22.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: He even, like, sounds really
smart all the time.

1270.44.text:
ROB WEGNER: Yes. When God said, "Let there
be light," and there was what?

1273.97.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Light.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.

1275.35.text:
ROB WEGNER: And it began with creation, and
everything was in harmony. There was harmony

1281.69.text:
in the souls of men and women and there was
harmony in their relationships and there was

1285.70.text:
harmony between them and creation and them
and God. And then we exalted ourselves and

1291.82.text:
we chose to put self above God. God said,
"I will always tell you what is good and right

1297.01.text:
and wise." And we said, "No. I know better."
And it shattered shalom. It shattered harmony.

1304.33.text:
Not just in us, but in our relationships and
in creation.

1306.86.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.
ROB WEGNER: And that's when the pursuit started.

1310.62.text:
God reached out to a man named Abraham. And
he said, "I'm going to heal what's broken.

1315.62.text:
I'm going to take what's shattered and put
it back together again. I'm going to redeem,

1319.36.text:
restore." And out of Abraham came a nation,
Israel. And guess what? Israel's a lot like

1323.62.text:
us. They just didn't have a clue. Couldn't
keep the covenant, couldn't keep their part

1327.87.text:
of the deal, and the prophets said, "There's
someone else that's coming. There's a Messiah

1332.26.text:
who's coming." And the prophets also talked
about this future that we're headed towards,

1337.60.text:
a beautiful and complete restoration where
everything will be made well, where everything

1343.70.text:
will be as it should be. Every nook and corner
of creation, the entire cosmos, will be what

1348.77.text:
God intended it to be. But we needed this
Messiah to come.

1351.56.text:
And then God came in Christ. He put on flesh
and blood. And Jesus did what Israel could

1357.95.text:
never do and what we could never do: keep
our part of the covenant, keep our part of

1362.97.text:
the deal. And he lived a perfect life. He
showed us what a real life looks like. He

1369.21.text:
invited us into the kingdom, the rule and
reign of God. He demonstrated it through living

1373.50.text:
the perfect life and through his miracles
and ultimately through his death and resurrection.

1378.37.text:
I don't know if you've heard, but after Friday,
Sunday morning he rose.

1384.91.text:
ROB WEGNER: He's alive now and forever more.
And now this redemptive covenant community

1390.52.text:
is called the Church, and it's not just for
Israel. It comes by grace. And we get to love

1396.91.text:
him and become like him and share him.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.

1398.85.text:
ROB WEGNER: And it's the greatest story that's
ever been told.

1400.75.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.
ROB WEGNER: You know, right now there's this

1403.78.text:
growing fervor -- and I'm sure it will last
all year long -- for Star Wars.

1407.76.text:
(Laughter.)
ROB WEGNER: You know, and people are literally

1410.43.text:
starting at 7:00 in the morning, and they're
going to go all the way through. All those

1414.47.text:
terrible movies that George Lucas made in
the middle. Those were horrible.

1417.79.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: They were. They were.
ROB WEGNER: The first three were amazing,

1421.06.text:
and then that next one, I was like, "George
Lucas, you've destroyed my childhood dreams.

1426.87.text:
ROB WEGNER: But J.J. Abrams is coming to save
the day.

1429.28.text:
(Laughter.)
ROB WEGNER: And so the new one. And you know

1431.58.text:
what? When we watch those stories, you know
what you want to do. You want to get out of

1434.52.text:
your seat and step into the story, don't you?
Man, I want to roll with Luke, and I want

1440.24.text:
to roll with Hans Solo. You know what I mean?
I want to put my arm around Chewbacca and

1441.99.text:
say, "What's up?" you know. And here's the
--

1444.92.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Just don't say Princess Leia.
ROB WEGNER: Here's the thing about this story.

1448.62.text:
Here's what we're going to do this year. I
mean we get to discover that is actually a

1452.62.text:
reality for us. We get to step into the greatest
story ever told. And we're going to spend

1458.62.text:
a year, from Genesis to Revelation. We're
going to walk through the story together.

1462.73.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Could you get a little excited?
(Laughter.)

1466.53.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Is Star Wars anywhere in
this script?

1469.66.text:
(Laughter.)
BRIAN PHIPPS: I'm just glad he didn't say

1471.95.text:
he wanted to hang with Princess Leia. That's
all I got to say about that.

1473.28.text:
ROB WEGNER: I'd like to see you with her hairdo,
though. That would be cool if you had the

1480.09.text:
little buns on the side.
BRIAN PHIPPS: I would take any hair at this

1486.61.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: So anyway. Just saying that
that's right there.

1489.50.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: So what we're going to do
is we're going to start in Genesis, and we're

1492.88.text:
literally going to follow God's story of redemption
all the way through the Bible this year. We're

1501.82.text:
going to go Genesis to Revelation in a year.
Now you can't cover it all in a year, but

1508.86.text:
we're going to hit the highlights. And we're
going to talk about look what God is doing

1513.44.text:
here, look how Jesus showed up in what he
promised Abraham, and look how Jesus showed

1518.22.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: -- the law, and look how
he was trying to speak to us through the prophets

1522.33.text:
and through the kings. And look what happens
with his birth and his life and his death.

1527.23.text:
And look what the Church does with it after
that. And then look at Revelation, which tells

1532.09.text:
how it's all going to end. And I've read the
end, and we win.

1534.80.text:
(Laughter.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I mean, we're going to study

1536.38.text:
that all the way through this year. And in
40 years of ministry, I have wanted always

1542.95.text:
to study all the way through the book in one,
big, long story. And we're going to get the

1548.28.text:
chance to do that. We're literally going to
start that January 3rd. You can't cover it

1553.50.text:
all, but we're going to cover a lot of it.
And it's going to be a blast.

1557.53.text:
Now, why do we feel that's important? There's
a passage I want to read you here from Psalm

1562.46.text:
145 that talks about the importance of everyone
knowing and sharing God's story. Listen for

1569.76.text:
it. "You're awe inspiring deeds will be on
every tongue. I will proclaim your greatness.

1577.36.text:
Everyone will share the story of your wonderful
goodness. They will sing with joy about your

1584.32.text:
righteousness."
Here's the deal, Brian: God wants all of his

1587.15.text:
followers to share his story with all those
who are not following him yet. But you can't

1593.28.text:
share what you don't know. You can't give
away what you don't have.

1597.82.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: I mean, that's extraordinarily
true. But you also really can't believe in

1602.26.text:
something that you don't fully know about.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.

1604.38.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: I just wanted to share my story.
I mean, this is so personal to me, to the

1609.21.text:
extent that I even named all of my children
Hebrew names or Old Testament names, because

1614.76.text:
I had this --
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Leia, Hans.

1617.65.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: There's no -- there's no Chewbacca
--

1621.31.text:
ROB WEGNER: Ebenezer.
BRIAN PHIPPS: -- in the Old Testament.

1624.04.text:
(Laughter.)
BRIAN PHIPPS: You know, Hannah, Samuel, and

1624.92.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: -- are all Old Testament names.
And I did that on purpose because there was

1629.27.text:
a part of my life -- and there's a lot of
folks that are online right now who probably

1632.24.text:
have the same experience. You kind of have
snippets of the Bible memorized -- Daniel

1636.19.text:
and the lion's den, Jesus and the kids -- I
mean, you know a lot of the pieces, but you

1640.95.text:
don't have a real confidence in the whole
story. And perhaps you've even be told by

1644.82.text:
a college professor or someone else in your
life that's pretty much said, "You know, it's

1648.91.text:
just a bunch of stories of fables and they're
not" -- "they're all disconnected. They're

1652.90.text:
written by hundreds of different authors"
and the like. And so I kind of walked into

1656.98.text:
this thing, even though I was raised in church,
with a lack of confidence in the scriptures

1660.99.text:
as a whole.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.

1662.03.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: And then when I started to do
this kind of thing in school and start to

1666.77.text:
study the story as a whole and see the thread
of that covenant idea, Rob, that you were

1671.15.text:
talking about as it worked its way through
Abraham and David and the prophets and on

1675.87.text:
into Jesus and stuff, all of a sudden you
see that, man, there was one author writing

1680.27.text:
all this through many different authors over
a two-millennia period. And you're going "whoa."

1686.45.text:
Like, for instance, how many of you knew that
Jesus was crucified on the same hill that

1692.99.text:
Abraham went to offer his only son? Fabulous
stuff. I mean, and how many of you knew that

1701.45.text:
Jesus was crucified on the day of Passover
which was the same time that God slayed the

1709.82.text:
firstborn son of all the Egyptians in order
to free his people and his firstborn son,

1717.29.text:
the blood of the lamb.
I mean, when you start to see those connections

1720.50.text:
you haven't seen before, you start to take
note and go "Whoa. I knew the end of the story,

1724.62.text:
but I didn't know what built up to it." And
my confidence in the scripture and therefore

1729.85.text:
God as a whole just (ratcheting up sound).
So, Hannah, Samuel, and Caleb came out of

1736.05.text:
that. So I can tell the story now, but I tell
it much more passionately now because now

1741.21.text:
I not only know the story and have more confidence
in it, but I see now where I fit into the

1747.91.text:
story that is that deep, man (motioning).
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Are you guys getting the

1750.73.text:
idea that we're excited about this?
(Laughter.)

1752.40.text:
ROB WEGNER: Yeah.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I mean, really and truly

1754.31.text:
we're fired up about it.
BRIAN PHIPPS: Yeah.

1756.02.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I don't know that any of
us have ever been this fired up about a teaching

1759.63.text:
plan for the year.
Another passage out of the Book of Joel that

1762.75.text:
I want to share with you. Listen carefully
to the words of the prophet: "Hear this, you

1767.52.text:
leaders of God's people. Listen, all who live
in the land. In all your history, has anything

1774.94.text:
like this happened before? Tell your children
about it in the years to come and let your

1779.81.text:
children tell their children. Pass the story
down from generation to generation."

1787.35.text:
That passage gives us three things about God's
story that are absolutely stand-out qualities.

1794.51.text:
And we'll be talking about these through the
year. But here's a preview of what's coming.

1800.23.text:
I'll start it.
The story of God is unique. No world religion

1809.40.text:
has its founder sacrifice his life for his
people except Christianity. No world religion

1818.80.text:
has prophesies coming from 1,500 years before
that are specifically fulfilled in Christ.

1826.96.text:
No other religion has somebody claimed to
be God, lived a perfect life, and then died

1834.18.text:
and then been raised from the dead to prove
it. It is a unique story. My journey was going

1842.33.text:
off to college and saying, "I'm done with
my parents' faith. I'm going to check out

1847.56.text:
every world religion there is, and I'm going
to become something that fits me." And back

1853.09.text:
then, I could cross my legs and sit Buddha
style.

1856.25.text:
(Laughter.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And, man, I did it all.

1858.95.text:
ROB WEGNER: You could -- you could actually
get up afterwards?

1860.88.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I could hum. I could get
-- dude, I could spring up.

1863.17.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: (Laughs.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I could get up without my

1865.27.text:
hands. We won't try that right now.
(Laughter.)

1867.04.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I might need both of you-all
to get me up right now.

1869.84.text:
But the reality is after studying and looking,
I came full circle back and rediscovered the

1877.07.text:
God that I'd heard about but had never known.
It is a unique story. And all year, we're

1883.76.text:
going to see its uniqueness.
Who's up, boys?

1886.26.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Him.
ROB WEGNER: Well, the story of God is also

1889.71.text:
for families. You'll notice the scripture
writer says these words: "Tell your children

1894.59.text:
about it in the years to come and let your
children tell their children." And the reality

1901.14.text:
is every family passes on to their children
what I would call a dominant story.

1906.63.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.
ROB WEGNER: All of us are profoundly shaped

1913.36.text:
by the dominant story that our parents passed
to us. It's what some people call your world

1920.54.text:
ROB WEGNER: It's the most compelling and controlling
informant in how you live your life.

1928.27.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: It is.
ROB WEGNER: And for most people, that dominant

1931.11.text:
story is some kind of weird fusion of what
the culture has said, the brokenness in their

1936.45.text:
family system, you know, and other bits and
pieces they've picked up along the way.

1942.93.text:
You know, a real common dominant story in
America is, you know, I want to grow up, and

1947.17.text:
I'm going to go to my dream college. And then
after my dream college, I'll get my dream

1950.56.text:
job. And then I'll get my dream house, and
then I'll get my dream spouse, and then we'll

1955.00.text:
have our dream children. And we'll go on our
dream vacation to get away from our dream

1959.37.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: That's a not -- that's a
--

1960.12.text:
ROB WEGNER: You know --
BRIAN PHIPPS: I know this story.

1961.61.text:
ROB WEGNER: Yeah. And then there's, you know,
the dream 401(k) and the dream retirement.

1965.79.text:
And then God gets to play this wonderful,
supporting role in the epic story --

1969.82.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: -- of me.
ROB WEGNER: -- of me and my American dream,

1972.24.text:
you know.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: My dream, yeah.

1973.45.text:
ROB WEGNER: And I think a lot of us have a
sense that the dominant story that we're living

1977.57.text:
in, that got passed down to us by our parents,
is not sufficient. We feel strangled by it.

1983.92.text:
We feel hindered by it. We feel incomplete.
And that's because the story that we need

1992.15.text:
is the capital S story.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.

1993.89.text:
ROB WEGNER: And this year, we're going to
equip families like never before so that moms

1999.27.text:
and dads and brothers and sisters and aunts
and uncles and grandmas and grandpas know

2003.94.text:
the story personally but then are also equipped
to be able to tell the story. So this is the

2008.70.text:
first time we've ever done this at Westside.
Everybody from the little beaners to teenagers,

2013.43.text:
all the way up to the real old people, we're
all going to go on this journey together.

2019.82.text:
Did you get that? Simultaneously, we're all
going to go on this companion --

2023.20.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Be amazing.
ROB WEGNER: -- journey. And that, I think,

2025.62.text:
is going to be transformative.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah. So the story's unique.

2030.64.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: The story of God is continuous.
Have you ever heard that statement that we're

2034.80.text:
always one generation away of Christianity
kind of going crazy and being gone? It's always

2041.37.text:
kind of pitched in that warning-type language.
We're one generation away from reaching the

2046.13.text:
whole world with the story.
ROB WEGNER: Right on.

2048.48.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Depends on how you look at it.
And I truly believe that -- you know, we started

2053.38.text:
by singing "This is Amazing Grace" and celebrating
"This is Amazing Grace." That's the story

2058.94.text:
is God is for us. He loves us. He chases us
in spite of our mess-ups. I mean, who doesn't

2064.75.text:
want to hear that story? Who doesn't want
that to be the dominant theme of their family?

2068.51.text:
ROB WEGNER: Uh-huh.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.

2069.21.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Well, that's the dominant theme
of this church family. God is for us. He loves

2075.81.text:
us. And he wants to see that story not just
told to our familial next generation, but

2081.85.text:
the next generation of the millennials and
the ones that will follow the millennials

2085.27.text:
and the generation post-millennial or whatever's
next, to start a movement of an increasing

2090.86.text:
measure of God fulfilling his story in us,
through us, and then beyond us.

2096.59.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I've got to tell this personal
story, guys. It's so important that this unique

2103.22.text:
story that is continuous gets passed down
to our kids and their kids and the next generation.

2112.45.text:
Our grandson, Justice, that I talk about continually
is in kindergarten this year, and he's attending

2118.61.text:
a very high academic, very Catholic school.
And it's been a phenomenal experience for

2124.93.text:
him. He loves his classmates. He loves his
teacher. I think he's got a crush on his teacher.

2131.13.text:
You know how kindergarten or first grade boys
can do that? It's really cute. He's always

2135.38.text:
hugging on her and talking about her, "Mrs.
Fox this" and "Mrs. Fox that." And he went

2141.52.text:
to his first Catholic Mass a few weeks ago,
which is not an experience that a five-year

2148.09.text:
old that's grown up at Westside knows much
about.

2150.91.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Sure.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And the teacher asked them

2153.79.text:
afterwards what they thought about it. And
Justice wasn't saying anything, which is unusual

2159.47.text:
for anybody related to a Southerland.
(Laughter.)

2161.86.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And she finally called on
him, and he said, "Well, Mrs. Fox, I'm sure

2167.92.text:
Mary was a very nice lady. I know she's the
mother of Jesus. I'm sure she was wonderful.

2173.87.text:
But I don't pray to Mary. I don't understand
why we're doing that. I talk straight to Jesus,

2179.80.text:
and he answers me." So she asked him to explain
his faith in Jesus. So he just stands up and

2187.17.text:
gives this five-year-old class of kindergartners
the gospel. Now, this is not because he's

2192.95.text:
odd for God. He went back to playing with
Legos two minutes later.

2198.85.text:
But it's because his parents have passed the
story on to him and because their parents

2205.26.text:
passed the story on to them. And it's this
unique, continuous, family story that is worth

2213.51.text:
telling and worth spending a year on.
So I am pumped about it and looking forward

2217.64.text:
to it. So "The Story's" going to be our focus
this year. You're going to hear "The Story"

2221.96.text:
a lot. And it refers to two things. One: It
refers to the continuous redemption story

2227.40.text:
that both these guys have talked about so
well, from Genesis to Revelation. But "The

2231.97.text:
Story" is also a reference to a chronological,
abridged version of the Bible. Two pastors

2240.79.text:
that are a lot smarter than we are, Max Lucado
and Randy Frazee, have put this together.

2247.35.text:
Every word in here is scripture. But they've
left out pieces of scripture. They've made

2253.19.text:
it read like a novel, from start to finish.
It's got 32 chapters. They're very readable.

2259.87.text:
There's an adult version of this book. That's
this one. There is a student version for our

2264.76.text:
middle school and high schoolers. And there
is a kids' version. How cool would it be for

2270.13.text:
our kids and our students to go all the way
through the entire Bible -- the story part

2276.14.text:
of the Bible -- in a year? And we're going
to tell you guys each week which part we're

2281.01.text:
studying, and you can read that chapter and
that part that week. This is an amazing, easy,

2286.78.text:
fun read. I can understand this --
(Laughter.)

2290.71.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: -- which is really, really
awesome. So that's what we're going to do.

2293.98.text:
Now, guys, there's a lot of ways that we're
going to encourage people to jump in. Let's

2299.87.text:
talk through what some of those could be,
because this starts next weekend, January

2305.38.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I mean, we're hitting it.
We're going -- literally, guys, it's going

2308.02.text:
to take us a year. It's going to take us a
full year to do this. This runs through Christmas

2313.57.text:
of next year, all of 2016, going through the
Bible. What are some ways people can jump

2319.32.text:
into the story?
ROB WEGNER: Well, first of all, I'd encourage

2321.92.text:
everyone to pick up not just a copy of "The
Story" for themselves but for somebody else.

2325.66.text:
In fact --
DAN SOUTHERLAND: And we're actually selling

2326.99.text:
them that way.
ROB WEGNER: That's right.

2327.74.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah. Two for -- two of these
for ten bucks.

2329.90.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Right.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Guys, you can't get a book

2331.73.text:
like that for five bucks. So don't walk up
and say, "I want one for five." No.

2335.21.text:
(Laughter.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Buy two -- they're two for

2336.98.text:
ten -- and give one away. Right?
ROB WEGNER: That's right. That's right.

2339.71.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I mean, you probably need
one. Here.

2341.15.text:
ROB WEGNER: I do. I'll take it.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah.

2342.87.text:
ROB WEGNER: And, Brian, I imagine the most
powerful way to experience this book is going

2348.30.text:
to be in community. So what kind of --
BRIAN PHIPPS: Yeah.

2349.63.text:
ROB WEGNER: -- opportunities will people have
for groups?

2350.63.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Well, be part of a small group.
We're going to start those off beginning of

2353.95.text:
the year like we always do, do another big
push in September if you're kind of catching

2358.68.text:
this thing later in the year. But listen,
you can get into a group anytime. All you

2362.84.text:
have to do is go onto westsidefamilychurch.com,
fast -- slashy forward thingy -- groups.

2369.29.text:
(Laughter.)
BRIAN PHIPPS: And -- whatever that is.

2372.75.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Backslashy --
BRIAN PHIPPS: Forward slash. There we go.

2373.99.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: -- forward thingy?
BRIAN PHIPPS: All right, Chewbacca.

2375.25.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Did you learn that in seminary?
BRIAN PHIPPS: Huh?

2377.81.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: "Backslashy forward thingy,"
is that a -- is that a Presbyterian term?

2381.79.text:
(Laughter.)
BRIAN PHIPPS: So get in a group.

2387.94.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: No, seriously. I mean, and -- but
several times throughout the year, we're going

2392.30.text:
to come back and just say, "Hey, get in a
group." This is a fun thing. If you learn

2396.87.text:
the story all by yourself, it's cool. You
learn how other people are assimilating that

2401.95.text:
story into their own soul and their life and
how it's affecting them, dude -- so I'd encourage

2406.63.text:
it.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Now, some of you may not

2408.80.text:
get in on this on the front end. Here's the
good news: It's in chapters. So you can join

2413.08.text:
at any point throughout the year. There's
a section that talks about "In the beginning,

2418.37.text:
God," and then there's a section that talks
about the law and a section that talks about

2422.34.text:
the prophets and the kings and the judges,
and a section talks about Jesus and his ministry

2427.63.text:
into the church in their time frame. So wherever
you come in during this year, you can jump

2432.83.text:
in and be part of this.
And by the way, we encourage you: Come every

2436.84.text:
week. Now here's why that's important, guys.
This matters. When we're in a series that's

2443.98.text:
about anger, let's say, you could miss a couple
of weeks and still get the gist of the series.

2449.68.text:
When we're walking through a whole portion
of the Bible every week, you want to be here

2455.81.text:
-- you want to be present -- or you want to
catch it online. That's the great news. You

2460.12.text:
can always catch it online.
So we want you to get a book, we want you

2464.34.text:
to get in a group, and we want you to catch
the service every weekend. Every weekend.

2469.68.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: I was going to go back and just
say the part of the groups things I forgot

2472.83.text:
about when I got stuck on the forward-slashy
thingy -- is brand-new groups. I mean, if

2478.08.text:
you're catching this --
DAN SOUTHERLAND: I really rattled you, didn't

2480.75.text:
I?
BRIAN PHIPPS: I rattled myself, I think.

2481.83.text:
But at the beginning of the year and in the
fall of next year, we're going to have just

2487.34.text:
a tremendous opportunity for very -- for you
to start a brand-new group. And really that's

2492.34.text:
the funnest way to do this is to just start
a brand-new group. It's easier to get going

2496.37.text:
in a brand-new group than one that's already
started. And we will walk with you all the

2501.27.text:
way through. You'll notice in your notes that
you can get online or whatever's coming up

2506.33.text:
on the screen right there. You can start a
brand-new group. We call it HOSTs. And this

2510.70.text:
is what it's like. If you can -- if you have
a heart for people, if you can open your home

2515.74.text:
or your place or whatever, if you can serve
a few snacks and turn on the TV, you can do

2521.24.text:
this with us. And we encourage you to do that.
And you can let us know you want to do that.

2525.57.text:
We would love it.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: There's another way that

2527.13.text:
you could jump into the story. That's get
connected to the Westside part of this story.

2532.56.text:
And we do an awesome thing here at Westside
all year long. We do a Get Connected every

2537.89.text:
month. Every month through the year. You can
also do that online. And we encourage you

2544.74.text:
to do that. Why? Because the story gets personal
when you join up with a group of other believers

2551.01.text:
locally, people you can do life with, that
are also in the story. My story is richer

2558.95.text:
and deeper because these two characters are
in it. My story is richer and deeper because

2564.53.text:
everyone in this setting is in it. My story
is richer and deeper because all you guys

2569.14.text:
online are part of it. And we want to do this
together. It's not a solo thing.

2574.10.text:
ROB WEGNER: Uh-uh.
DAN SOUTHERLAND: You can't follow God solo

2576.51.text:
and do the whole deal. We are made and designed
to need each other. So all of those ways:

2583.24.text:
come every week, get a copy of the book, get
in a group -- you can even host a group -- make

2588.87.text:
sure that you're checking it out online if
you can't be here for one of the services,

2593.91.text:
and then also do that Get Connected thing
so you're part of a local group.

2599.38.text:
Guys, what are your last excitements about
the story?

2602.40.text:
ROB WEGNER: You know, Brian and I this last
week had a chance to watch U2's show --

2608.32.text:
BRIAN PHIPPS: Oh, my gosh.
ROB WEGNER: -- that they did live in Paris.

2612.86.text:
And I've seen U2 live twice. And one of the
things that's unique about U2 is there's this

2620.22.text:
sense that everybody who's in the audience
is in the band. And they always bring people

2624.21.text:
up on stage. And during that show, you know,
there was a steady parade of audience members

2629.09.text:
that Bono would bring up. And these people
-- you could tell -- they're like (makes excited

2632.25.text:
ROB WEGNER: I mean, they're about to just
explode with joy. You know, and they know

2636.98.text:
every word and they're singing along. And
it's pretty awesome when you get an invitation

2642.41.text:
to be a part of the greatest rock band in
history -- that's my personal opinion --

2645.89.text:
(Laughter.)
ROB WEGNER: -- but it's nothing compared to

2648.33.text:
when Jesus, the champion of the universe,
the redeemer and the restorer of all things,

2654.05.text:
says, "You want to be in my band?" And the
name of his song is "This is Amazing Grace."

2660.03.text:
That's our story. And that's where we're going
to go this year.

2663.19.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Yeah. It's going to be a
fun, fun year.

2665.61.text:
Brian, anything to add?
BRIAN PHIPPS: Nothing more.

2667.37.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Hey, guys, we invite you
into the story of Jesus this year. It truly,

2674.83.text:
truly is the story of "Amazing Grace."
(Music and singing.)

2814.70.text:
TROY KENNEDY: Lord, you are good, and your
mercies endure forever. We bring this offering

2822.20.text:
to you because of your presence in our lives,
because of your passion, Lord, because of

2835.10.text:
your grace, because of your mercy, because
of your power, because of

2843.90.text:
your ever-present, overwhelming, extravagant
love. We lift you up in this place, Lord.

2854.10.text:
We lift you up because your glory is our desire.
(Music and singing.)

3019.70.text:
(Video plays.)
DAN SOUTHERLAND: We want to thank you for

3020.54.text:
joining us for Church Has Left the Building,
and we want to invite you again to jump into

3026.41.text:
"The Story" next week. We start out January
3rd. We'll be talking about how do you know

3033.51.text:
the Bible is real, how can you trust it, how
can you believe it, and then we jump straight

3039.19.text:
into Genesis and run all the way through to
Revelation. It's going to be an amazing year.

3045.02.text:
2015 was easily the best year Westside has
ever had. God's favor has been all over this

3052.29.text:
place, and we know that's him and not us.
ROB WEGNER: That's right.

3056.25.text:
DAN SOUTHERLAND: Join us in 2016 for the next
step of "The Story." God bless you, guys.

3062.29.text: We love you a bunch. See you soon.
